For Adams, depicting civil rights leader Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in a state of repose was a radical yet logical choice. “When you’re dealing with oppressive structures, being able to relax is a revolutionary thing,” he says. And yet there are very few images out there of Black activists at leisure. Painted from an Ebony magazine photo of King vacationing at a Jamaican resort with his family in 1967, the piece is meant to humanize a figure so often viewed as one-dimensional. “What I’m showing here is Martin as a whole person,” Adams says. “In doing so, I’m shedding light on the type of activism that can exist today—how it can be a part of anyone’s life. People can protest and then go out to lunch with their friends after. One act doesn’t negate the other.”He believes that the juxtaposition of poem and painting helps clarify the political intent behind the work. “I like the fact that they aren’t necessarily a narration of each other but do speak to each other.” In the same way that Adams’s painting offers a multidimensional look at King, whose birthday we honor in January, Giovanni’s poem presents a candid portrait of Black life in which joy and pain, abundance and loss, revolution and repose exist simultaneously. “It’s a chance for the viewer or reader to meditate on the connection between these two objects,” Adams says. “It’s about taking a moment to look within.” —Hilary Cadigan3-1593 400 Mulvaney StreetBy Nikki GiovanniIt was a small houseIn a small neighborhoodTheir bedroom was in the front overlooking
